subject: Re: testXXXX must return void?
msgSnippet: ... have to physically look at the result to verify it. You code what you expect in the test and the test runner tells you whether the results match your
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:

> The whole point of JUnit is automate those tests so that you do not
have to physically look at the result to verify it. You code what you
expect in the test and the test runner tells you whether the results
match your expectations. This is in perfect alignment with the
purpose of JUnit.

That is a good thing but there is more than one way to think about
it.

> There are many reasons to write tests this way. I suggest reading
the available literature, especially Kent Beck's Test-Driven
Development by Example, http://www.xprogramming.com and
http://www.junit.org

Thanks, maybe you should do some more reading too and listen to other
developers to expand your perspective to include viewpoints other
than your own.

>
> If JUnit wastes your time,

word twisting, never said that.

>If you think JUnit is beneficial,

I do, and as I indicated I have plenty of experience with automated
testing using xUnit.

>then you have to change your approach to work with JUnit. If you
want to do something slightly different than JUnit, then you have to
find that or build it yourself.
>
> I think those are your options.

How about just hacking junit? Make it do something the designers
never intended. That's another option.
